cab.content: MINISTRY OF FOREIGN AFFAIRS,BRUSSELS, August 27th,1923. Monsieur 1'Arabassadeur, The Belgian government have examined with all the consideration due to the government of a country which is the friend and ally of Belgium the memorandum which His Excellency the Principal Secretary of State for.Foreign Affairs addressed on the 11th instant to the Belgian Ambassador in London. Belgium does not forget that every time when her independence has been in danger England has come to her aid. In 1914 Great Britain, faithful to her engagements; responded to the appeal ad&expressed to her by the Belgian government when their territory was invaded, in contempt of treaties, and generously expended all her strength to assure the common victory. The two hundred thousand subjects of ' - the British Empire who sleep in Belgian soilbear 9$jK * it tf 2, .bear witness to this. These memories, which no Belgian canforget, create lasting bonds of friendship and confid-ence. It was under the influence of these bondsthat the Belgian government endeavoured to meet theBritish views and to accomplish a work of concilia-tion by drafting the letter which Baron Moncheur hadthe honour to hand to Lord Curzon on July 30th last.The Belgian government therefore were painfullyimpressed when they found that their intentions andefforts had not been appreciated by the Britishgovernment, and that the latter had not consideredthat the arguments presented by the Belgian govern-ment were of sufficient interest to justify aseparate answer;er. It is therefore necessary that theBelgian government should reply to the criticismsaddressed to them and explain themselves afresh.In order to do this usefully end to assist in solving the vital problem which separates the allies m 3. . ;Vi"v^Allies and concerns the peace of the world,the Belgian Government do not consider itindispensable to take up all the points raisedby the British memorandum of August 11. they feel it is preferable to continue to search for practical solutions, capable of winning theagreement of all the Allies, and with this purpose in view to persevere in the efforts which theyhave, never ceased to make since the Armistice -efforts which have repeatedly received recognitionfrom the Allied Governments and especially fromthe British Government, The Belgian Government are however unable topass over in silence certain points in the british note which affect them more particulaiily, the more so as one of them, that respecting Belgian priority,has produced a painful impression in Belgium. The/ thus/ The Belgian Government will therefore deal with these points first. They will endeavour- vour to do so briefly and in the most friendly spirit, but also wi-th complete frankness. A. - REMARKS IN REGARD TO THE BRITISH NOTE OP AUGUST 11. ^-iJiaa .7*. The first point which has arrested the atten- tion of the British Government is that the Belgian Government in their letter of July 30, while remained- ning in favour of a joint answer to Germany, should not have made the slightest allusion to the text of the British draft of that reply. This remark can only be the result of a misunderstanding,. The letter of July 30 does in fact state expressly"that if the considerations which they have ventu-"red to set forth are favourably received, the"Belgian Government believe that an agreement could"be reached on the text of a joint reply". thus because they had examined the British draft withthe attention which, it deserved and had apprecia-ted its substance and form. This draft corres-ponded with their views much more closely than theletter which accompanied It. But as it was clearlystipulated that the two documents were Inseparable,it seemed to the Belgian Government logical first of all to make known their opinion on the covering letter and to ask for further precise information which would put them in a position to grasp more clearly the exact purport of the draft reply, to whichthe covering letter provided a commentary. A second remark of the British Governmentcalls for an explanation. They state that the Bel-belgian Government lay down as a condition for a corn-promise that the substance of their claims shouldbe regarded as "conceded in advance". Nothing isfurther from the thoughts of the Belgian Govern-ment than such an idea. On the contrary. It hasalways seemed to the Belgian Government, and itappears to then,today, with,more force than ever,that the Allies should agree on the reparation2.Purport of the Belgian sugggestions. They problem bef ore anything else... Once an agreement has been reached on the solution of this problem, the Belgian government are convinced that it would become easy to reply jointly to Germany; and it is with, a view to arriving at such' agreement.. that the Belgian government put forward certain suggestions which should serve as the basis of discussion. In so doing, they were endeavouring to simplify the task of the allied governments; but they never said nor wished to say that these suggestions must be accepted as they stood and that they regarded them, as immutable.. 3. ' Legality of the occupation of.the Ruhr. when they decided in agreement with the French government to occupy the valley, of.the Ruhr, the Belgian government were mindful of the fact that all the allied governments acting together had several times over contemplated the execution of the very measures to which the Belgian government thanfound themselves obliged to resort. The measures which they adopted were therefore only those which these governments had unanimously contemplated on argument - They-Tecallected in particular that at Spa,with a view to attaching sanctions to. their decisions in regard to Germany!s defaults in the deliveries of reparation coal, all the representatives of thePowers without exception placed their signatures uponthe protocol of July 16th, 1920, providing by commonagreement for the possible occupation of furtherGerman territory, the Ruhr district or any other. Nor were they unaware of the fact that while at other meetings an inter-allied exchange of views had taken place in regard to the question of occu-pying the Ruhr district, such exchange of views1had only dealt with the opportuneness of that occu-pation, whereas its legality or more precisely itslegal basis had never even been questioned. These precedents, and the interpretation thusunanimously placed upon,the Treaty.of Versaillesby the principal Allied Powers who drafted andsigned that instrument, are moreover easily explain-ed by the precise and formal terms of paragraph18 in Annex 2 to part'VIII of that Treaty. pi : l&* argument on this point.- Their reason for not doing so is that they consider it preferable not to pro- long a discussion which appears to them out of place, in view of the many important questions of essential interest to which they wish to see the Allied Governments devote their chief attention. resistance has ceased, and duration of The Belgian Government feel that they cannot let pass without comment the statement of the British Government that Belgium as well as Prance lias met with a categorical refusal the British suggestion that the occupation of the Ruhr should come to an end when guarantees and pledges, more pro- ductive than that occupation, shall have been de- vised and put into operation, They therefore find themselves obliged once more to define their inten- tions, in regard to which they had, however, hoped that no doubt would exist. On January 10 last the Belgian Government in- formed the German Government that in consequence of the defaults of Germany declared by the Reparation Commission.they/ 7'9.9they had decided, Concurrently with the French Govern-ment, to send into the Ruhr a mission of control,composed of engineers and invested with the necessary powers for assuring the application of the programmeslaid down by the Reparatipn Commission, and for taking all measures necessary for the fulfilment of thoseprogrammes,- On this occasion the Belgian government felt hound to declare that they had no idea of resort-ing to an operation of a military nature or of a.political character. They were only sending'Into the ruhr such troops as were necessary to safeguard themission and to guarantee the execution of its task. Nodisturbance nor change was to be introduced Into thenormal life of the population, who could continue to.work in order and quiet. The intention of the Belgian Government thereforewas that the contemplated measures of control were riotin ar;y way to Impede the economic activity of this dis-trict, the occupation of which was to be as it wereinvisible. It is no fault of the Belgian Government ifthings have turned out differently. If the character of the enterprise has had to be modified, and if the French and Belgian governments have found themselves compelled to take certain measuresof constraint, it is because of the. opposition and re-si stance which the German Government themselves haveorganised in order to frustrate the economic mission andthe dispositions which we had taken in conformity withthe Treaty. It nevertheless remains true that the occupationof the Ruhr is in principle, in spirit and in formessentially a seizure of pledges. Belgium was con-fronted by Germany's defaults in the execution of her obligations, which.had been declared officially and inaccordance with the Treaty by the Reparation Commission;she therefore considered that it behoved her to have recourse to the seizure of these pledges. On titeday when passive resistance shall have ceased theBelgian Government will settle with the French Govern-ment the measures designed to ensure a progressivereturn to the situation contemplated on January10th last. Thus an important change willtake place., and we should be happy if the pledge in...... - 734in our hands could then be placed under inter-alliedsupervision. further, the.French and Belgian governments have repeatedly declared that their intention was to relaxtheir hold on this pledge by degrees in proportion toGermany*s execution pf her obligations to make repa-rat ion. " They desired, it is-true, to create- in Gerrmany the will to.pay; but they knew that that will.,could only be definitely crystallised when the wholeGerman people had felt that it was to its interest to fulfil its undertakings.. /Thus,.the Belgian government, could not allow theintention, to be ascribed to them - even indirectly -of prolonging this occupation indefinitely or indeedfor all time, or of refusing to examine the Britishgovernment's suggestion in regard to putting intooperation certain productive pledges in Germany underinter-allied supervision; for the Belgian governmenthave received no precise definition of these pledges;they know nothing of their nature and productivecapacity; and in the absence of agreement between all the allies on this point they are obliged to preserve the sole guarantee which they have taken. ; But in any case it would he impossible foi"us to evacuate the Ruhr in return for merepromises by the Germans; previous experience has demonstrated to us what value can beattached to such promises, what we need isthe actual execution by Germany of her obliga-tions in respect of reparation. 5. Belgian priority. Finally, the British government in their note recall the fact that out of a priority of 2-g- milliard gold francs recognised, as due to belgium, the latter has already receivedapproximately f; and that the sums which shewas to receive in virtue of this priorityhave not been reduced in proportion to thetotal reduction which is to be expected inGermany's payments. The British notefurther states that Belgium has in additionobtained release from her war debts. One wouldbe entitled to conclude, from these observationsthus presented that in the view.of the Britishgovernment Belgium has already been treated with too great favour, and that she woulddisplay a bad grace if she proved exacting. Nothing could be more painful to the Belgian ..... Belgian government than to think that suchan interpretation of the. British government'intentions reflected the latter's real feelings.It would indeed he based on a misconception ofthe reasons for which, and the conditions underwhich, that priority was granted. The Belgian government desire to recall,with a firmness which in no wise excludes theirdue appreciation of the friendly sentimentsalways displayed towards them by the Britishgovernment, the fact that the limited prioritygranted to Belgium is but the execution - in a degree which in her view is, far from complete -of the undertakings contracted towards herduring the war, the justification for whichlay in her exceptional position. Great Britain, together with fee other allied powers, recognised that Belgium had inter-intervened in the war unprompted by any consider-ation of political interest, and knew thatshe would not seek any advantage from thepeace; she therefore gave the Belgian govem-ment the formal assurance that after hostilitieswere over, Belgium would receive full reparationfor the immense damage endured by.her solely because she had been faithful to her engagements towardsthe Powers who had guaranteed her neutrality. ' this assurance was given by the British government ina solemn diplomatic document; it has been repeatedlyrenewed in the most formal declarations of hermost authoritative statesmen. It is the themeof point 7 in the 14 points of President Wilson'declaration of January 8th/ 1918. In such circum-stances, the Belgian government together with thewhole of Belgian public opinion have been dismayedto see the thing which, according to their profoundconviction, Is merely the partial recognition of aright which they are fully entitled to regard assacred, denounced as a treatment of special favour. The Belgian government believe that it is notsuperfluous to recall at this point the negotiations with led up to the granting of the 2 milliard goldfrancs priority to Belgium. The Belgian plenipotentiaries went to Versaillesin firm reliance on the declaration of SainteAdresse and on the promises made to Belgium by thevarious heads of governments, which gave her the right right to hope that Belgium would receive full repa-ration. It soon became clear that sUch a hope mustbe abandoned. Priority for the devastated regionswas then put forward. This claim appeared to theallies still too high. The.Belgian plenipotentiariesasked for indemnity in respect .of the sum of about 6milliard marks left by the Germans in Belgium, onwhich the Germans had imposed a forced rate of ex-change at'l.25 francs; this request likewise was not accepted. The allies declined to settle this question by the Treaty and left it open between Germany, andBelgium. It is known that.the.German government,themselves recognising the wrong done to Belgium by theintroduction of the marks, have negotiated repeatedlywith a view to indemnifying the Belgian government. As Belgium had been occupied for more than 4 years, as her industries had been utterly ruined, andas hundreds of thousands of her workmen had been reduc-ed to idleness, her recovery was only possible if sheobtained within a short period the partial payment ofthe indemnities due to her. Despite their efforts, the.Belgian plenipoten-tiates at the Peace Conference had not at first been - 16 - i been able to secure the grant of a guarantee on this subject.' Belgian public opinion was alarmed at this, and the Belgian delegates were obliged to inform Messrs. Clemenceau,Wilson and Lloyd George on April 29, .1919 that in these circumstances they would not be able to adhere to the draft treaty without reference to their government and parliament. These were the circumstances in which theFrench, American, British and Italian delegates were induced to examine to what extent satis-faction could be given to Belgium; and on June24, 1919 the President of the Conferencecommunicated to the Belgian delegates andundertaking signed by Messrs, Clemenceau,Wilson, Lloyd George and Sormin^, whereby itis recognised as "equitable that a certain"priority should be granted to Belgium in"respect of payments made by Germany by way of"reparation". Consequently, it is stipulatedin this document that "the undersigned, in"the name of their -respective -governments,"agree that out of the first cash received"from Germany in respect of reparation Belgium"shall receive, on account of the reparation"payments to which she is entitled,"the equivalent of 2,500,000,000 gold francs." Tli is ***** This engagement is absolute; it had been made in consideration of the immediately indispensible monetary needs of Belgium, andwithout taking account the total sums expected from Germany. It would consequently havebeen altogether unjustifiable to reduce theamount of the priority in proportion to thepayments effected by Germany, and moreovernone of the Powers which signed the under-taking of June 24. 1919 has up till now made such a suggestion. For the same reasons and under thesame conditions - i.e. in consequence of herpeculiar position,- Belgium also obtainedexoneration from her war debts. The Belgian government accepted these terms, and signed the treaty in reliance on theundertaking of their great allies. Their pur-pose in so doing was to prove to the world that although Belgium ted been dragged into the mosttragic of wars, contrary to all right and all'justice; that-although she had been thefirst to be invaded, the last to be delivered,and had undergone the most rigorous occupa- tion____ Hition throughout the war, Belgium nevertheless in-tended in the hour oi victory to, display moderationand contribute to the utmost of her powers towardsfacilitating the establishment of a just and reason-able peace. This moderation, from which she in-tends never to -depart, has been displayed by herafresh and several times over in the very exerciseof her right of priority. In point of fact, accord-ing to the text in which that priority is enshrined,it is-to'rank "immediately after that for the armies of occupation - apart from the reservation made forthe feeding of Germany. It thus followed that once the expenses ofthose armies had been covered, Belgium was toretain all the payments in cash or in kind which she might have received from her debtor, and also had the right to claim for herself, until herpriority right has been extinguished, all cash whichthe Reparation Commission might have receivedfrom Germany or on Germany's account. Finally,she had the right to require on May 1st, 1921 thatthe Allied Governments should reimburse to her thevalue of all payments and deliveries in kind which Germany .... 19.Germany had made to them. Such was the procedure formally sanctioned by the signature of the representatives of four great Powers.Belgium might have insisted upon its observance. She did not do so, and made in this respect import-ant and successive sacrifices. Thus at, Spa in July 1920 she renounced up tillMay 1st:, 1921 the provision v/hich certainly gave thegreatest concern to the British as well as to the Frenchand Italian governments, namely that which gave her theright to require the reimbursement of the. sums ordeliveries in kind which France and England, as well asItaly, had received from Germany, once the expenses ofthe armies of occupation had been met. She further consented, in the event of a Germanloan being Issued, to claim the recovery of herpriority out of that loan up to 50% only. On August 13th, 1921 she agreed to spread out overfour periods of three months each the payment of thebalance.of her priority, and thus brought greatrelief to the Allied Treasuries since she was entitledas from May 1st, 1921 by the above-mentioned Spaagreement to the reimbursement of all that the Allies allies received. But the position of Germany-was Meaning worse0It became increasingly certain that the allies would only be able to obtain from her reduced payments incashe while the deliveries in kind would continue on a relatively large scale. In view of this new situationBelgium once more consented not to require during theyear 1922 from her allies the reimbursement of the valueof these deliveries in kind, and particularly and above all of the quantities of coal delivered to France andof the sums levied by England under the "ReparationRecovery Act". The latter amounted to about 100 mil-lion gold marks per annum, and were assimilated to theaforesaid deliveries. From that time onwards Belgium contented her-self with retaining the payments in cash and*the deliveries in blind made to her by Germany, thus reduc-ing the exorcise of her priority to the minimum, and.allowing her allies despite that priority to receive,before she had been completely satisfied, sums the magnitude ox which we will presently recall. She even W9nt further in this this direction, and tier sacrifice soon proved to be greater still; for' from July 1922 onwards the GermanGovernment declared themselves incapable of contin- :uing to effect the promised monthly payments infuture. This declaration brought about a gravecrisis in inter-allied relations. With a view to meeting this crisis, and atth-3 risk of compromising her privilege, Belgiumintervened afresh; instead of exacting payment in cash she accepted five six-monthly bills, represent-ing the five monthly payments which Germany was due to effect in 1922, At the same time she agreed that the Germangovernment should effect a payment of 2 millionpounds sterling to the clearing Offices; sheagreed to this solely because her allies asked her to do so, and although the latter had themselvesrecognised that her reparation claims .had priority over those of the Offices in question. We see therefore that for the last threeyears Belgium has constantly agreed to fresh modi-fications of her priority, to the detriment of herimmediate interests, to the benefit of those of her allies, and above all to the benefit of the main-tenance of the Entente to which she is ao loyallyattached. 6. What Belgium has received from Germany. The British note insists upon the point that the Belgian priority becomes more advantageous in proportion as the payments of Germany diminish. This statement is somewhat surprising,for it was precisely to proviue against acontigency of this nature that the prioritywas granted to us: for it must not be forgotten that this priority does not give us a single gold mark more than our share ofthe reparations; it only allows us to receive more rapidly a fraction of this share, whichconstitutes an advantage in time, not an advantage In the sums to be received. It is obvious that this advantage would amount to nothing if Germany paid to eachof her creditors what she owes them, butit is precisely because' Germany does not' payall her creditors that the priority comes into play. There is nothing- astonishing or unforeseen .... creditedunforeseen in this. The situation isthe same as that which arises in everydaylife when a creditor has claimed a privilegeor a mortgage. These are only of interestwhen the assets of the debtor are insufficient to settle his debts completely. The British note states that Belgiumhas already received by virtue of her priority-one and a half milliards of gold marks, "a"sum far exceeding the receipts of any other"Power". One would think in reading this phrasethat Germany had hitherto paid nothing ornext to nothing to other countries, and thatthe sum received by Belgium constituted the major part of those paid out by Germanysince the signature of the Treaty of Peace. This Is not the case. If the booksof the Reparation Commission are consulted itwill be seen that up till now Germany has been - 24 - 747'credited with about 5rmilliards ofgold marks paid in cash or in kind, partly onaccount of the armies of occupation and asrepayment of the advances in respect of coal,and partly on account of reparations (thesefigures of course exclude the value of cededState or imperial property). Out of these 5i.milliards of gold marksBelgium has been debited under the same heads"with 1,729 millions of gold marks, that isto say less than one-third. Another calculation can be made, in which only those sums would be taken into account which Germany has expended,either in foreign currency or in paper marks destined for the armies of occupation, or in paper (marksdestined to pay her own nationals fordeliveries in kind. We even think thatthese calculations would be more interest-ing interesting than the former one, since they representthe real amount which Germany has disbursed. To be absolutely sure that we remain withinthe facts we will exclude from these calculations,as far as Belgium is concerned, the value of thematerial (wagons, locomotives, etc.) delivered in virtue of the armistice conventions; as far as .Great 'Britain is concerned, the value of the merchant ships which she has received from Germany. Mow,, if we exclude, as suggested above, thearmistice material, Belgium has received up to now on account of her armies of occupation, ofthe repayment of her advances on account of coal,and for her priority, 1,258 millions of goldmarks. To this must be added, ii it is ^desiredto take into account the liquid assets re-ceived by Belgium, about forty-one millions of goldmarks coming from the payments made by the German Clearing ...... Clearing Office. Total 1..299 millions of gold, marks. Under the same, heads the various other allies have received up to now;- .Great Britain 1,297 millions of gold marks. We must mention in order to avoid any mis- understanding that of the sums received by Great Britain and France, the part representing the costs of the armies of occupation and repayment of advances on account of coal is considerably greater than the corresponding part of the sums received by Belgium; but nevertheless from the point of view of Germany the payments made have tha same importance, . The Belgian government have alwaysthought, and they have continually so informedtheir allies during the negotiations of thelast few months, that it is above all important for them to agree upon the amount of theGerman debt and upon its division amongst them-selves. They are convinced that once agreement has been reached upon these points, the othermatters under discussion would be much more easily settled. For this reason they have presented to fee British government, as alsoto the French and Italian governments, detailedstudies on this subject. They therefore note with pleasure thatappreciable progress has been made in the courseof the last exchanges of views. Whilst theyare desirous of explaining their proposalsafresh, the Belgian government tITink it advisable to specify at once the points with regard towhich this progress -has taken place. 2. In the first place it is useful and important to note the unanimous acceptance ofthe principle, so well demonstrated by feeItalian government, of the close relationship ' -between the questions of reparations and - inter-Allied .... inter-Allied debts. For the important point for the nations of the Entente is to know the net sums which they are to receive; and, in order to fix this amount, it is not enough to calculate the payments which Germany willmake; the sums which must be paid out under the heading of war debts must also be known.All are today agreed as to this. 3. Secondly, all have accepted.the idea, for which the Belgian government contended in their note of July 30th, that if it is wise to take into consideration the debtor's capacityof payment in fixing the amount of the Germandebt, it is also just as well as necessary notto lose sight of the essential needs of the creditors. The Belgian government are glsrd of this declaration. They had never thought of depriv-.ing Great Britain of the reparation to which she has a right. They quite understand thatshe too requires to -receive money; they ap-preciate the great sacrifices made by herfor the common victory; they are not forget-ful of the material losses suffered by herduring the war; they know her economic diffi-culties, the number of her unemployed, and the considerable ....'. considerable financial effort she has made. The Belgian-government therefore consider the decision of the British government to spring from a desire for conciliation and agreement and they sincerely appreciate it. 4. Now therefore the sums demanded are known, except as regards the French and Italian debts to the United States. Without prejudice to the attitude of the other Allies, whose. full liberty must be reserved and whose assent is necessary, one can conclude from what lias been set forth above, that the German debt can be considerably reduced from the amount fixed on May 5th 1921. So great is this reduction that, as the Belgian government have shown in the greatest detail in the studieswhich they have submitted to their Allies, the German government will beyond possibility of doubt be enabled, after a transition period, to meet the annuities corresponding to the balance remaining. 5. In their note of July 30th last the Belgian government In the course dT an examina- tion of the measures by which a settlement of the reparation question could be facilitated, recommended that, in the event of a complete or partial cancellation of the 0 bonds, the percentages to be received by each Ally out of the sums paid by Germany should be revised. The British government consider- that there is no justification for this request, since the principle of the division between the Allies is not affected by a change of the total ..... total to which the percentages apply.. The Belgian government consider, on thecontrary, that there is'a correlation betweenthe Spa agreement as to the percentages andthe schedule of payments fixing the Germandebt. A modification of the second agreementcalls for a readjustment of the first. When Belgium accepted the schedule ofpayments of May 5th 1921 she expected, in accor-dance with the Spa agreement, to receive 8%of 132 milliards gold marks, represented by Aand B bonds for 50 milliards and C bonds for82 milliards. If the German debt is reducedsimultaneously with the inter-Allied debtsby the partial or total cancellation of the Gbonds, the value of which corresponds! with theinter-allied debts, Belgium would receive no compensation for the G bonds surrendered by her.If she were only to receive her share of the Aand B bonds, she would be deprived of theadvantage which was recognised as terswhen the Treaty of Versailles freed her from her Inter-Allied debts, and indirectly she ,would now be made to pay the debts of which shewas relieved at-Versailles. This evidentlycannot be the intention of the British govern-meht. The Belgian government feel convincedthat they need only draw attention to this anomaly for it to be taken into account. 6.
